injuries.name: Minor Cuts and Scrapes
symptoms: Small cut or scrape on skin

first_aid_steps.instruction: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before treating the wound
Clean the cut gently with clean water to remove dirt and debris
Apply gentle pressure with a clean cloth or bandage to stop bleeding
Apply an antibiotic ointment if available to prevent infection
Cover with a sterile bandage or adhesive strip
Change the bandage daily and monitor for signs of infection

emergency_triggers: Deep cut that won't stop bleeding after 10 minutes of pressure
Cut caused by a dirty or rusty object
Signs of infection (increased pain, redness, swelling, pus)
Cut on face, joint, or hand that may need stitches
prevention_tips: Use cutting tools carefully and away from your body
Keep work areas clean and well-lit

injuries.name: Minor Burns (First-Degree)

first_aid_steps.instruction: Remove the person from the heat source immediately
Cool the burn under cool (not cold) running water for 10-20 minutes
Remove any jewelry or tight clothing near the burn before swelling occurs
Cover the burn with a sterile, non-stick bandage or clean cloth
Take over-the-counter pain medication if needed (ibuprofen or acetaminophen)
Do NOT apply ice, butter, or ointments to the burn

emergency_triggers: Burn is larger than 3 inches in diameter
Burn affects face, hands, feet, joints, or genitals
Skin appears charred, white, or leathery (third-degree burn)
Burn is caused by chemicals or electricity
Victim is a child or elderly person
prevention_tips: Keep hot liquids and foods away from table edges
Test bath water temperature before bathing children
Keep matches and lighters out of children's reach

injuries.name: Sprains and Strains
symptoms: Limited ability to move the affected joint
Popping or tearing sensation at time of injury

first_aid_steps.instruction: Follow the R.I.C.E. method: Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation
REST: Stop activity and rest the injured area
ICE: Apply ice pack for 15-20 minutes every 2-3 hours for the first 48 hours
COMPRESSION: Wrap with elastic bandage (not too tight)
ELEVATION: Keep the injured area elevated above heart level
Take over-the-counter pain medication if needed

emergency_triggers: Severe pain and inability to move the joint
Numbness or tingling in the affected area
Inability to bear weight on the injured limb
No improvement after 48 hours of home treatment
prevention_tips: Maintain good muscle strength and flexibility

injuries.name: Nosebleed
symptoms: Blood flowing from one or both nostrils
Blood dripping down back of throat
Sensation of liquid in nasal passage

first_aid_steps.instruction: Sit upright and lean slightly forward (not backward)
Pinch the soft part of the nose firmly for 10 minutes
Breathe through your mouth while pinching
Apply a cold compress to the bridge of the nose
After 10 minutes, release pressure and check if bleeding has stopped
If still bleeding, repeat pinching for another 10 minutes

emergency_triggers: Bleeding continues for more than 20 minutes
prevention_tips: Use saline nasal spray to keep nasal passages  moist

injuries.name: Choking

first_aid_steps.instruction: If person can cough, encourage them to keep coughing
If cannot cough/speak: Stand behind the person
Make a fist with one hand, place it above their navel
Grasp your fist with the other hand
Give quick, upward abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver)
Repeat until object is dislodged or person becomes unconscious
If person becomes unconscious, call emergency services immediately and start CPR

emergency_triggers: THIS IS AN EMERGENCY - CALL EMERGENCY SERVICES IMMEDIATELY
Person cannot breathe, talk, or cough
prevention_tips: Avoid talking or laughing while chewing
Keep small objects away from young children

injuries.name: Suspected Bone Fracture
symptoms: Inability to move the affected area

first_aid_steps.instruction: Call emergency services immediately - DO NOT MOVE THE PERSON unless necessary
Immobilize the injured area - do not try to realign the bone
Apply ice packs to reduce swelling (wrapped in cloth, not directly on skin)
If bone is protruding, do not push it back - cover with sterile dressing
Treat for shock: keep person warm and lying down
Monitor breathing and consciousness until help arrives

emergency_triggers: THIS IS A SERIOUS INJURY - CALL EMERGENCY SERVICES
Fracture involves spine, neck, hip, or skull
prevention_tips: Keep floors clear of tripping hazards
Use proper safety equipment at work
Maintain bone health with calcium and vitamin D

injuries.name: Poisoning

first_aid_steps.instruction: CALL POISON CONTROL CENTER OR EMERGENCY SERVICES IMMEDIATELY
Try to identify what was ingested and have the container ready
Do NOT induce vomiting unless instructed by poison control
If person is unconscious, position them on their side
If substance is on skin, remove contaminated clothing and rinse skin with water
Monitor breathing and consciousness until help arrives

emergency_triggers: THIS IS AN EMERGENCY - CALL POISON CONTROL OR EMERGENCY SERVICES
prevention_tips: Store chemicals and medications in locked cabinets

injuries.name: Head Injury

first_aid_steps.instruction: If severe symptoms, call emergency services immediately
Keep the person still and lying down
Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth to reduce swelling
Monitor for worsening symptoms
Do not give medication without medical advice
Keep person awake and alert for at least a few hours

emergency_triggers: Clear fluid draining from nose or ears
prevention_tips: Wear helmets during sports and cycling

injuries.name: Insect Sting or Bite

first_aid_steps.instruction: Remove stinger if visible by scraping with credit card (don't pinch)
Wash area with soap and water
Apply ice pack for 10-15 minutes to reduce swelling
Apply calamine lotion or hydrocortisone cream for itching
Take antihistamine if needed for itching
Elevate the affected area if possible

emergency_triggers: Swelling of face, lips, or throat
THESE ARE SIGNS OF SEVERE ALLERGIC REACTION - CALL EMERGENCY SERVICES
prevention_tips: Avoid wearing bright colors or floral patterns outdoors
Don't wear perfume or scented products

injuries.name: Eye Injury

first_aid_steps.instruction: Do NOT rub the eye
For small particles: Blink several times to try to remove
Pull upper eyelid over lower lid to help flush out particle
Flush eye gently with clean water or saline solution
If object doesn't come out, cover both eyes and seek medical help
For chemical exposure: Flush immediately with water for 15-20 minutes

emergency_triggers: Object is embedded in the eye
Sharp pain or inability to open eye
Blood in white part of eye
prevention_tips: Wear safety glasses when using tools

emergency_numbers.general: Call your local emergency number (911 in US, 999 in UK, 112 in EU)
emergency_numbers.disclaimer: For life-threatening emergencies, always call emergency services immediately

general_disclaimer: This chatbot provides basic first-aid guidance only. It is not a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. For serious injuries or if you are unsure, always seek immediate medical attention.
